question: So - for an object to exist at all, it must exist in the fourth dimen- sion....and that fourth dimension is duration....Time! I'm coming to that. But first, consider! Why is it that we usually ignore the fourth dimension? Because we have no freedom to move in it. We can move in the other three -- up, down, forward, backward, sideways. But when it comes to Time, we are prisoners. Do you follow me, Anthony?
answer: George! You've given a most lucid explanation and all that! But I don't think I entirely understand.

question: Look! There are a lot of things in the world you don't understand, aren't there?
answer: Of course! Quite a number.

question: But you don't refuse to believe in them because of that?
answer: Not if I can see the proof with my own eyes.

question: You're ready then? Doctor Hillyer, would you care to lend me your hand?
answer: Where did it go? Do you seriously expect us to believe that?

question: Certainly.
answer: But you just said it hasn't really moved.

question: That's correct.
answer: Then why can't we see it?

question: No you're not. - You've been behaving oddly for over a month now. I'm not leaving until you tell me what's on your mind.
answer: I appreciate your gesture, David, but if you don't mind I'd rather you left me alone.

question: You have changed, George. Enormously.
answer: I'm sorry. I'll try.

question: Why this preoccupation with Time? Don't go simple on me, George! I quite agree with you. But here we are and we have to make the best of it.
answer: You may have to. I don't. I prefer the future.

question: You're not seriously saying you can do it?
answer: You saw the experiment this afternoon, didn't you?

question: I saw a toy machine vanish. But I'm certain there are a number of ways of doing that trick. Any magician at the Hippodrome could probably do it. No, I would not! I have no desire to tempt the laws of Providence and I don't think you should. It's not for man to trifle with.
answer: Now you sound like Hillyer and Kemp.

question: There is something in their common sense attitude to life. George, I speak to you as a friend. More, as a brother. If that machine can do what you say it can...destroy it. Destroy it, George, before it destroys you.
answer: You must have plans for New Year's Eve. Don't let me keep you.

question: Mary isn't well. We decided to stay home with the baby. But why don't you come home with me. You haven't seen little Jaime for a long time.
answer: I can't.

question: What's stopping you?
answer: I just want to see the old century out by myself.

question: Will you promise me that you won't leave the house tonight?
answer: I promise you, I won't walk out of the door. David! Please don't think me un- friendly! - Come over to dinner - next Friday. Won't you?

question: Very well.
answer: Fine...and will you bring the others with you?

question: Filby! I expected more of an enthusiastic greeting from... Was?
answer: Were you a friend of father's?

question: Yes...yes...I've been away.
answer: He was killed in the war...a year ago. Oh, him. Some inventor who disappeared around the turn of the century. - If you're interested in that house, forget it. You can't buy it or even go inside.

question: Why is that?
answer: My father was executor of the inventor's estate and he refused to liquidate it. I often chided him on that account, but he felt positive that the owner would return some day. - Some people hereabouts think it's haunted. Who are you, sir?

question: Just a stranger who once knew your father.
answer: I see. Have you been at the front, sir?

question: Front? What front?
answer: Why the war, of course.

question: What war?
answer: Great heavens, man, don't you know we've been at war with Germany since nineteen fourteen? I thought perhaps you had seen action in France...or maybe... Perhaps a cup of tea would make you feel better. Won't you come in?

question: No...no, thank you.
answer: You're sure you're alright, sir?

question: Yes, I'm quite alright. Goodbye, Jaime.
answer: As I went along, I gained experience in handling the Machine. I found that I could stop for a day, an hour, or even for a second to observe, then go ahead for a year or two. - Thus I was able to see the changing world in a series of glimpses.

question: Good heavens, that's a dress?
answer: This was intriguing. I wondered just how far women would permit this to go. I began to grow fond of that mannequin. Maybe because, like me, she didn't age. Suddenly, in nineteen forty I began to be buffeted from side to side. My first thought was that the Machine had a mechanical defect or a part had worn out. The last time I had stopped was in nineteen seventeen, twenty three years ago. And the war with Germany was still waging - now in the air with flying machines. It didn't seem possible they could go on fighting all these years and still have the means of fighting. Then I realized the truth of the matter. This was a new war. There must have been an interval of peace in between these wars. Yet they had learned nothing but to prepare even more effective means of destroying one another. I decided to push on into time and see the outcome. The fighting in the sky lasted only a few moments. By nineteen forty five it was over, but I continued on a few more years before pausing for another glimpse of my silent, never aging friend. It vas reassuring to find that she hadn't changed. Only her costume. Provocative to say the least. I wondered what she would look like ten years hence. At first I wondered if my Machine and I were the cause of the panic. I was to soon find out we weren't.

question: I can't understand you.
answer: Confounded radio in this thing. Makes more noise than it does sense.

question: Filby!
answer: My name is Mister Filby. - Didn't you hear the air raid siren?

question: You mean that horrible screeching?
answer: It wasn't constructed for its aesthetic values, you know, but to warn silly young fools like yourself to get down into the shelter. Now go on.

question: But I'm perfectly comfortable and I find your store magnificent. What splendid achievements, what gigantic strides mankind has taken, what...
answer: Come on, young man. We'd better be going before the mushrooms start sprouting. You do look familiar. Haven't we met somewhere before?

question: Indeed we have. Right here. Many years ago.
answer: I was sure of that, but the exact time escapes me.

question: It was two wars ago, I believe. Nineteen seventeen. I'm afraid it's going to take me a little time to explain... You see...
answer: The last alert...hurry!

question: Listen to me! It's important.
answer: Hurry! Hide 'til the All Clear!

question: Well, and why not? Help her!... Are you all right? Why did I what? Must have been fifty of your friends watching you drown. Not one of them so much as lifted a finger. - A curious attitude - in a curious world. Aren't you the least bit interested in what I am...where I come from? Doesn't anyone age in this land of yours? What's your name? How do you spell that?
answer: Spell?

question: Write! - Can't you write? Look! And what are your people called?
answer: Come. We must go in.

question: In my time a berry this size would have made news in every civilized country. Sir, perhaps curiosity has died. Perhaps even courtesy has died, but I have come a long way and there are things I would like to know. Because I shall return to my time and they will ask questions such as what kind of government rules your world.
answer: We have no government. There are no laws.

question: Doesn't anyone work?
answer: No. It grows. It always grows.

question: But it must be planted, cultivated, nurtured...unless... Unless you have an economy so well organized that you can devote all your time to study and experimentation. Am I right?
answer: You ask many questions.

question: Books will tell me what I want to know. Books will tell me all about you. Yes...they do tell me all about you! What have you done? Thousands of years of building and rebuilding creating and re-creating so that you can let it crumble to dust. A million yesterdays of sensitive men dying for their dreams. For what? So you can swim and dance and play. I am returning to my time! Not to tell of the uselessness of the struggle - not to tell of the hopeless future - but only so that I can die among men!
answer: I heard you pounding...I came to tell you...

question: How do you open that panel?
answer: No one opens it. Only the Morlocks.

question: Morlocks? - Who are the Morlocks? Why are you afraid of the Morlocks? Tell me.
answer: When they call, we must go below.

question: Do the Morlocks live beneath the earth? Why must you obey their command?
answer: They give us the food we eat, the clothes we wear. We must do as they command.

question: What happens to your people when they go below?
answer: It is night.

question: Only children are frightened by the dark. - But then you are a child, aren't you? I'll build a fire.
answer: Where are you from?

question: Get me a few more twigs. What was it?
answer: I never saw it before.

question: Do you know that the first thing which separated man from the rest of the mammals was his knowledge of fire? No, I suppose you don't. The next great stride came with the discovery of the wheel. Do you know what that is? I'm sorry I was angry with your people. I had no right to be. No more than if I had visited the Island of Bali in my own time. You were safe inside your great house, yet you came out into the night to warn me. The one characteristic which distinguished man from the animal kingdom was the spirit of self sacrifice. You have that quality, Girl. I'm sure all of your people have it. All it requires is someone to reawaken it. I shall try if you'll let me. Will you?
answer: I do not understand you, but I believe you.

question: That's a good start. - Now try to tell me...who or what are the Morlocks? Are they people or animals? What do you know about yourself? The past? Don't your people ever speak of the past?
answer: There is no past.

question: Don't you ever wonder about the future?
answer: There is no future.

question: Listen! Do you hear? Machines!
answer: No...Morlocks.

question: You mean those animals run machines?
answer: They are Morlocks.

question: I know, but have you seen the machines?
answer: No, only heard of them.

question: Who told you?
answer: The talking rings.

question: What sort of rings?
answer: Rings that talk.

question: Can you show me these rings? Are these the talking rings?
answer: Yes.

question: They speak?
answer: Yes.

question: Of what?
answer: Things no one here understands.

question: I'll be back. Weena! Where are you, Girl? What's happening? Tell me! Stop! What do you mean, all clear?
answer: Yes, the rings have told us that story.

question: But you didn't listen. You didn't learn anything. All that is left is fear...a blind animal fear. Ages ago men were taught to hide in the ground when the sirens blew... taught to run from a raining death... but those men are dead! And so are the men who slaughtered them. Don't you understand? You are slaves of a dead past... You don't even own your souls. You're led to slaughter like sheep! What about those who went below? How are they to come back?
answer: They never come back. Nobody can bring them back.

question: Are you sorry?
answer: Sorry? - Sorry for what?

question: That you have to stay.
answer: Yes. - I am sorry because I could tell so much to the people of my own time... I could tell them about the happiness and sorrow the future has in store for them. They could learn from it...or would they?

question: You don't want to stay, do you?
answer: It isn't that, but I don't fit here anymore than you would in my time.

question: I would like to see your time.
answer: No, Girl, you wouldn't be very happy there.

question: Do you have someone like me - there?
answer: No. No one like you. But there are friends who will miss me. - As a matter of fact, I'm probably late already.

question: Women?
answer: No, men. There is a woman too, of course! She looks after my house for me. She is sixty-two years old. - Much older than you are.

question: How do they wear their hair?
answer: Who?

question: The women in your time.
answer: Up!

question: Up? - How?
answer: Like this.

question: Show me. Would I be pretty?
answer: Yes...you would be. More than pretty. I wish we could go back together, Weena, back to my own time...or to times before that when the world was young. We could...
